messages.text:
Are any of these possible?
- Artifacts are persisting across builds, and we're inadvertently using something from master in a release-1.5 build
- Something is off with how we're trying to link things on FreeBSD
- We're inadvertently downloading a BB LLVM from master in non-master builds

elements.text:
Are any of these possible?
- Artifacts are persisting across builds, and we're inadvertently using something from master in a release-1.5 build
- Something is off with how we're trying to link things on FreeBSD
- We're inadvertently downloading a BB LLVM from master in non-master builds

messages.text:
So, currently we have the <#C01F9PX2UMU|ci-failures> channel, which gets a message every time a Buildbot fails on the `master` branch of the `JuliaLang/julia` repository.

Would it also make sense to get a Slack message whenever a CI job fails on the `master` branch of a stdlib that lives in an external repository (Pkg.jl, Statistics.jl, Downloads.jl, etc.)? 

We could put those Slack messages into the same <#C01F9PX2UMU|ci-failures> channel, or we could have a separate #stdlib-ci-failures channel for those messages.

elements.text: So, currently we have the
channel, which gets a message every time a Buildbot fails on the
master
branch of the
JuliaLang/julia

repository.

Would it also make sense to get a Slack message whenever a CI job fails on the
master

branch of a stdlib that lives in an external repository (Pkg.jl, Statistics.jl, Downloads.jl, etc.)? 

We could put those Slack messages into the same
channel, or we could have a separate #stdlib-ci-failures channel for those messages.

messages.text: I think it might be too noisy/confusing to post those Slack messages into the <#C01F9PX2UMU|ci-failures> channel. So I've created a separate <#C01QADURXU4|stdlib-ci-failures> channel for failures from stdlibs that live in external repositories.

elements.text: I think it might be too noisy/confusing to post those Slack messages into the
channel. So I've created a separate
channel for failures from stdlibs that live in external repositories.
